content.question: The figures below indicate forces acting on a rod in different situations. The lengths of the force vectors are proportional to the magnitudes of the forces. In which situation is the rod in both translational and rotational equilibrium?

choices.label: The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the left at the bottom of the rod and a force vector pulling to the right at the top of the rod. The force vectors are equal in length.
The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the left and a force vector pulling to the right both at the top of the rod. The force vectors are equal in length.

The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the right at the top of the rod and a force vector pulling to the right at a point less than half way up the rod from the bottom of the rod. The force vectors are equal in length.

The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the right at a point that is more than halfway up the rod from the bottom of the rod. There is also a force vector pulling to the left at the same height on the rod. The force vector pulling left appears to be a little more than half the length of the force vector pulling right.

The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the left at the bottom of the rod and a force vector pulling to the right from a point that is halfway up the rod from the bottom of the rod. The force vectors are equal in length.

content.answer: The figure shows a rod with a force vector pulling to the left and a force vector pulling to the right both at the top of the rod. The force vectors are equal in length.
